THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Bangladesh,  with  a  population  of  about  163  million  in  2016  and  a  land  area  of 
147,570 square kilometers (km), is among the most densely populated countries in the world, and 
one of the most vulnerable to climate risk. Two thirds of the country is less than 5 meters above 
mean sea level, in the world’s largest tropical river deltas of the Ganges, Brahmaputra, and 
Meghna.  Insufficient  rural  transport,  inadequate  market  infrastructure,  and  climate  change 
impacts are major constraints to agriculture development. The government’s Seventh Five Year 
Plan, FY2016–FY2020 has put forward strategies to overcome the challenges and constraints to 
agricultural development.1 
 
2.  Rural connectivity is a key component of rural development in Bangladesh, and road 
transport is the dominant mode of transport. Rural roads contribute significantly to generating 
increased agricultural income and employment opportunities, alongside promoting access to 
economic and social services. In Bangladesh, the Local Government Engineering Department 
(LGED)  owns  and  maintains  rural  roads.  The  total  road  network  of  Bangladesh  spans 
374,245 km, of which 352,943 km (94%) are rural roads. Many of these roads were constructed 
in 1990–2010 on earthen embankments owned by  union parishads (rural councils) or  zila 
parishads (district councils). Since 1995, the government, with the support of the international 
development community, has continued to expand and improve the rural road network. Despite 
this, rural connectivity in Bangladesh remains weak, impeding physical and economic access to 
goods and services. Only about 40% of the rural population has access to all-weather roads and 
only 28% of the rural roads are paved.  
 
3.  The proposed project will improve the road network connecting the rural population to 
agriculture value chain development zones, to pave the way for more opportunities to engage in 
agricultural production and agribusiness development. It will improve about 1,700 km of rural 
roads to all-weather standards in 34 districts located in five divisions,2 and enhance the capacity 
of  the  rural  infrastructure  agency  to  address  institutional  constraints  relating  to  rural  road 
development. It will also finance enhancements to the country’s rural road master plan to enable 
the selection of priority roads for improvement using a geographic information system covering 
the entire country.   
  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) will be provided for Institutional 
Strengthening of the Bangladesh Rural Road Sector for Sustainable Development. It will support 
the  LGED  in  improving  sector  management  performance  by  implementing  institutional 
development initiatives and bringing in international expertise. The TA will focus on (i) road asset 
management,  including  performance-based  maintenance;  (ii)  road  safety;  and  (iii)  climate-
resilient design and construction.  
5.  The large knowledge component is more suited to TA than a loan but will have a significant 
positive impact on current and future investments.  
                                                
1  Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission. 2015. Seventh Five Year Plan: FY2016–FY2020. Dhaka. 
2  Chattogram, Dhaka, Khulna, Rajshahi, and Rangpur divisions.

2 
   
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
6.  Output:  Rural  infrastructure  agency  capacity  enhanced.  This  will  consist  of 
implementing institutional development initiatives to improve the LGED’s sector management 
performance. International best practices related to institutional and management structures for 
managing the overall rural road network will be studied and adopted to strengthen the LGED’s 
capacity in (i) road asset management (including performance-based maintenance), (ii) road 
safety, and (iii) climate-resilient design and construction. The TA will  facilitate the LGED’s 
exposure to international practices related to these fields.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,250,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support 
in the form of staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions.   
8.  The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the TA. It will be implemented over 15 months, and is expected to 
start on 1 April 2019 and end on 30 June 2020. The LGED in the Local Government Division of 
the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development, and Cooperatives will be the executing 
agency. A Dhaka-based project management unit established within the LGED will support the 
implementation. The project management unit will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants.

11.  Consulting services. The TA will be implemented over 15 months and will require about 
34 person-months of consulting services (about 17 person-months international and 17 person-
months national) (Table 2). The team of consultants will be recruited by ADB in accordance with 
the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) under one package using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. A simplified technical 
proposal will be used for the selection of a firm. Disbursement under the TA will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).
